qas.question: When were the plans to update USB 3.0 to 10 Gbit/s revealed?
What actually happened whenever USB 3.0 was updated?

answers.text: The group ended up creating a new USB version

qas.question: What does the USB 3.1 standard increase?

answers.text: the data signaling rate to 10 Gbit/s in the USB 3.1 Gen2 mode

context: A <a0_0>January 2013<a0_0/> press release from the USB group revealed plans to update USB 3.0 to 10 Gbit/s. <a1_0>The group ended up creating a new USB version<a1_0/>, USB 3.1, which was released on <a2_0>31 July 2013<a2_0/>, introducing a faster transfer mode called SuperSpeed USB 10 Gbit/s, putting it on par with a single first-generation Thunderbolt channel. The new mode's logo features a "Superspeed+" caption (stylized as SUPERSPEED+). The USB 3.1 standard increases <a3_0>the data signaling rate to 10 Gbit/s in the USB 3.1 Gen2 mode<a3_0/>, double that of USB 3.0 (referred to as USB 3.1 Gen1) and reduces line encoding overhead to just 3% by changing the encoding scheme to 128b/132b. The first USB 3.1 implementation demonstrated transfer speeds of 7.2 Gbit/s.
